questions.text: Identify the audiogram. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Noise-induced hearing loss

 

The audiogram shows:

 

  • Both air and bone conduction curves are close together (no air-bone gap)
  • Normal hearing at lower frequencies (250 Hz, 500 Hz, 1000 Hz, 2000 Hz)
  • Sharp characteristic dip at 4000 Hz (4 kHz)
  • Bilateral involvement (shown in both red color for right ear and blue color for left ear)
  • This pattern is typically seen in factory workers exposed to loud noises

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Otosclerosis: Shows conductive hearing loss with Carhart's notch at 2000 Hz (2 kHz), not 4000 Hz. Also has significant air-bone gap which is absent here.

Option C. Meniere's disease: Shows sensorineural hearing loss with up-sloping curve affecting low frequencies. Does not show characteristic dip at 4000 Hz.

Option D. Acoustic neuroma: Shows a banana-shaped or trough pattern affecting middle frequencies, with poor speech discrimination. Does not show isolated 4000 Hz dip.

Educational Objective: 

 

Noise-induced hearing loss has a characteristic audiometric pattern with a sharp dip at 4000 Hz, typically bilateral and symmetrical.

 

  • Dip at 2000Hz on BC curve - Otosclerosis
  • Dip at 4000Hz - Noise induced hearing loss
  • Cookie bite audiogram - Congenital hearing loss mostly
  • Trough shaped audiogram - Acoustic neuroma
  • Up-sloping curve with SNHL - Meniere's disease (low frequencies involved)
  • Down-sloping curve with SNHL - Presycusis (high frequency loss) {Presbycusis - age induced hearing loss. Treatment: hearing aid}.
  • High frequency audiometry is used for detecting ototoxicity.

questions.text: Identify the structure given in the image: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incus

 

The structure given in the image is the incus.

 

The malleus has head, neck, handle (manubrium), a lateral and an anterior process. Head and neck of malleus lie in the attic. Manubrium is embedded in the fibrous layer of the tympanic membrane. The lateral process forms a knob-like projection on the outer surface of the tympanic membrane and gives attachment to the anterior and posterior malleolar folds.

 

The incus has a body and a short process, both of which lie in the attic, and a long process which hangs vertically and attaches to the head of stapes.

 

The stapes has a head, neck, anterior and posterior crura, and a footplate. The footplate is held in the oval window by annular ligament.


Other Options:

 

Option A. The malleus is the largest ossicle and is shaped like a mallet. The parts of the malleus are the head, neck, handle (manubrium), and anterior and lateral processes. The head and neck lie in the attic.

 

The tympanic membrane is connected to the handle of the malleus.

 

Option C. The stapes has a head, neck, footplate, and anterior and posterior crura. The annular ligament holds the footplate of stapes in the oval window.

 

 

The joints between the ear ossicles are synovial joints. A saddle-shaped joint is present between the incus and malleus. Incus and stapes articulate via a ball and socket joint.

 

Options D. Vomer A facial bone forming part of the nasal septum, unrelated to the middle ear.

Educational Objective:

 

The incus is one of the three auditory ossicles in the middle ear. It plays a critical role in hearing by transmitting sound vibrations from the malleus to the stapes.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 9

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway: (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Cochlear nucleus
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Inferior colliculus
  5. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 - 1 - 3 - 4 - 5

 

The auditory pathway is the sequence of neural structures that sound information travels through from the ear to the brain for processing. The correct sequence from the initial sensory input at the ear to the higher centers of the brain is as follows:

 

2. Spiral ganglion : Contains the cell bodies of the auditory nerve fibers. These neurons receive mechanical sound vibrations converted into electrical signals by the hair cells of the cochlea.

 

1. Cochlear nucleus : The first brainstem nucleus where auditory nerve fibers synapse. This nucleus begins the central processing of auditory information.

 

3. Superior olivary nucleus : Receives inputs from both cochlear nuclei and is involved in binaural cues for sound localization.

 

4. Inferior colliculus : A midbrain nucleus that acts as a major relay and integration point for auditory information.

 

5. Medial geniculate body : Part of the thalamus that acts as the final relay station for auditory information being sent to the auditory cortex in the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA). 
    1. Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve
    2. Cochlear Nucleus
    3. Superior Olivary nucleus
    4. Lateral lemniscus
    5. Inferior colliculus
    6. Medial geniculate body
    7. Auditory cortex
  • The spiral ganglion situated in Rosenthal's canal contains bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells join to form the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve which ends in the cochlear nuclei.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a-2, b-4, c-3, d-1

 

The correct match for Wullstein’s classification is a-2, b-4, c-3, d-1

 

  1. Type II – 2. graft placed over the incus
  2. Type III – 4. columella tympanoplasty
  3. Type IV – 3. Cavum minor
  4. Type V – 1. Fenestration tympanoplasty

 

  1. Type II (Ossiculoplasty): Malleus partially eroded; ossicular chain reconstruction involves placing a graft over the incus.
  2. Type III (Columella Effect): Malleus and incus eroded; new TM coupled to the stapes head, referred to as columella tympanoplasty.
  3. Type IV (Cavum Minor): Stapedial head also eroded; new TM and new ossicular coupling to the stapes footplate.
  4. Type V (Fenestration Operation): Creating a fenestra and coupling the ossicular chain to the scala vestibuli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wullstein’s classification of tympanoplasty provides a systematic approach to different types of middle ear reconstructions based on the extent of ossicular damage and required surgical repair.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man has arrived with a gradual swelling on the left side of his face persisting for two weeks. He had a prior incident of trauma involving wood, which occurred two months ago. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the nasal passages and paranasal sinuses reveals a mass within the subcutaneous tissue of the left cheek. Examination of a tissue sample obtained via biopsy indicates the presence of a foreign body granuloma, with positive staining observed using PAS and GMS methods. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phycomycosis

The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Phycomycosis /Mucormycosis. GMS positive confirms this.

It is fungal infection which may prove rapidly fatal. It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs. 

Other Options:

Option A. Midline lethal granuloma: This is a term historically used to describe aggressive midline facial granulomatous diseases, often linked to conditions like granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis). It does not fit the biopsy findings or clinical scenario described here.

Option B. Foreign body granuloma: Although the biopsy indicates the presence of a foreign body granuloma, the positive PAS and GMS staining suggests a fungal etiology, which is characteristic of Phycomycosis.

Option D. IgG4 granuloma: This is associated with IgG4-related disease, which presents with different clinical and histopathological findings, not typically involving PAS and GMS positive fungal elements.

Educational Objective:

Phycomycosis should be considered in patients with a history of trauma, swelling, and positive fungal stains (PAS and GMS), particularly if they have underlying conditions like diabetes or immunosuppression.

questions.text: What is the length of the external auditory canal in an adult? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 24 mm

 

Explanation:

 

The external auditory canal in an adult measures about 24 mm along its posterior wall. This is the standard anatomical length of the external auditory canal. The canal is not straight but has a slight S-shape, with the outer part directed upwards, backwards, and medially, while the inner part is directed downwards, forwards, and medially.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 16 mm: This is incorrect for the total length of the external auditory canal. However, 16 mm specifically represents the length of the bony part of the external auditory canal, which forms the inner two-thirds of the total canal.

 

Option B. 20 mm: This is incorrect. The external auditory canal is longer than 20 mm in adults.

 

Option D. 28 mm: This is incorrect. The external auditory canal is shorter than 28 mm in adults.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The external auditory canal in adults measures approximately 24 mm along its posterior wall and consists of a cartilaginous part (outer one-third, approximately 8 mm) and a bony part (inner two-thirds, approximately 16 mm).

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient arrives at the clinic with complaints of nasal obstruction on the right side and sporadic occurrences of blood-stained nasal discharge. The CT scan results are depicted in the image provided. What might be the potential underlying reason for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inverted Papilloma

 

An elderly patient with unilateral nasal obstruction, epistaxis and a mass visible points to a diagnosis of Inverted Papilloma.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Maxillary carcinoma arises from maxillary sinus lining and presents with facial paresthesia, lacrimation and pain.

 

 

Option C. Esthesioneuroblastoma/ Olfactory neuroblastomas are tumors arising from the basal layer of the olfactory epithelium in the superior recess of the nasal cavity. They usually present as a soft tissue mass in the superior olfactory recess involving the anterior and middle ethmoid air-cells on one side and extending through the cribriform plate into the anterior cranial fossa.

 

 

Option D. Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma is seen exclusively in males. Commonly presents with profuse epistaxis and nasal obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inverted Papilloma should be considered when an elderly patient presents with unilateral nasal symptoms and imaging reveals a mass, especially when the presentation includes epistaxis and nasal obstruction without the severe pain or neurological symptoms that might suggest a more malignant etiology.

questions.text: What test is not used for testing olfaction? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arnold stick test

 

The Arnold stick test is not a recognized method for assessing olfaction. The name does not correspond with standard or commonly used olfactory tests, which typically involve the identification or differentiation of specific odors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Smell Diskettes: These are used in screening tests for olfaction, where reusable diskettes are impregnated with different odorants. Participants are asked to identify scents from a list, often aided by illustrative questionnaires.

Option C. UPSIT: The University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test is a widely recognized and comprehensive olfactory test. It is self-administered and involves scratching odor-impregnated booklets to release smells, which the test-taker must then identify.

Option D. CC-SIT: The Cross-Cultural Smell Identification Test, a shorter form of the UPSIT, consists of 12 items and is designed for quick administration, making it practical for use in diverse populations and clinical settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tests used for olfaction are as follows:

 

  1. Smell diskettes are used as a screening test for olfaction. Reusable diskettes are used with the application of 8 different odorants. A questionnaire with illustrations is used to score the patient.
  2. University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT) is a commercially available, self-administered test used to assess the function of an individual's olfactory system via smell identification. It uses microencapsulated odorants, which are released on scratching standardized odor-impregnated test booklets.
  3. The 12-item version of UPSIT, also known as the Cross-Cultural Smell Identification Test (CC-SIT), is useful for quantifying smell loss when less time is available. This test serves as a means to reliably assess olfactory function in less than 5 minutes.
  4. The Sniffin' Sticks test is a new test of nasal chemosensory performance based on pen-like odor-dispensing devices. Semi-objective assessment of the patient's olfactory performance by means of 3 subtests: threshold test, identification test and discrimination test.

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, volume 2, Page No. 1233

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of left ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Quinsy

 

The image shows quinsy also known as a peritonsillar abscess.

 

It is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

 

The clinical features are sore throat/ dysphagia, drooling of saliva, trismus, ipsilateral otalgia, and fever.

 

EXAMINATION FINDINGS

 

  1. The tonsil, pillars and soft palate on the involved side are congested and swollen. Tonsil itself may not appear enlarged as it gets buried in the oedematous pillars
  2. Uvula is swollen and oedematous and pushed to the opposite side.
  3. Bulging of the soft palate and anterior pillar above the tonsil.
  4. Mucopus may be seen covering the tonsillar region.
  5. Cervical lymphadenopathy is commonly seen. This involves jugulodigastric lymph nodes.
  6. Torticollis. Patient keeps the neck tilted to the side of abscess

 

Investigations - Contrast-enhanced CT or MRI shows the abscess and its extent. Needle aspiration of an abscess provides material for culture and sensitivity of bacteria.

 

The management of quinsy is by antibiotics and incision & drainage to drain the abscess followed by interval tonsillectomy 6 weeks later.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pharyngitis: Typically presents with a sore throat and possible fever but lacks the severe localized symptoms and findings of quinsy.

 

Option B. Parotid abscess: Would likely present with swelling and pain in the parotid gland area, externally visible.

 

Option C. Bezold's Abscess: An infection that spreads from the mastoid process into the surrounding tissues, which would involve more distinct signs of ear and mastoid involvement.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Quinsy is a severe infection requiring prompt recognition and treatment to prevent complications. It distinctly affects the peritonsillar area, leading to significant local and systemic symptoms that guide its diagnosis and management.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 299

questions.text: Which opening is present posterior to the marked structure in the image? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Eustachian tube

 

The marked structure appears to be the inferior turbinate, and:

 

  • The Eustachian tube opening is located 1 cm posterior to the posterior end of inferior turbinate
  • This represents the pharyngeal opening of the Eustachian tube
  • It connects the middle ear with the nasopharynx
  • The opening appears as a vertical slit on the lateral wall of the nasopharynx
  • Forms an elevation called torus tubarius

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Onodi cell: This is a posterior ethmoid cell that extends superolateral to sphenoid sinus and is closely related to optic nerve. It is not located posterior to inferior turbinate.

Option C. Sphenopalatine foramen: This opening is located posterior to the middle turbinate (not inferior turbinate), about 1 cm behind its posterior end.

Option D. Sphenoid sinus: Opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, which is located above and posterior to superior turbinate, not inferior turbinate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Eustachian tube opening is located 1 cm posterior to the posterior end of inferior turbinate on the lateral wall of nasopharynx.

choices.text: Prevention of scar tissue formation in Laryngotracheal stenosis

questions.text: Topical application of Mitomycin C is commonly used in the treatment of which condition? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prevention of scar tissue formation in Laryngotracheal stenosis

 

Explanation:


Mitomycin-C is used post-operatively in laryngotracheal reconstruction to prevent adhesions and fibrosis. In the treatment of subglottic stenosis, after procedures such as laryngotracheal reconstruction with cartilage grafts or resection of stenosed segments, Mitomycin-C is specifically applied to prevent scar tissue formation that could lead to recurrent stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoscopic management of Angiofibroma: This is incorrect. Mitomycin-C is not used in the management of angiofibroma. These tumors are typically managed with surgical excision, preoperative embolization, or radiation in some cases.

 

Option B. Management of Sturge-Weber syndrome: This is incorrect. Mitomycin-C is not used for Sturge-Weber syndrome. This vascular condition typically requires different management approaches.

 

Option C. Treatment of Skull base osteomyelitis: This is incorrect. Skull base osteomyelitis treatment typically involves long-term antibiotics and sometimes surgical debridement, but Mitomycin-C application is not part of the standard treatment protocol.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mitomycin-C is an antifibrotic agent applied topically during laryngotracheal procedures to inhibit fibroblast proliferation and prevent adhesions and stenosis formation, making it particularly valuable in the management of laryngotracheal stenosis.

questions.text: Where is the electrode placed in cochlear implant procedures? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Scala tympani

 

The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the Scala tympani.

 

A cochlear implant works by producing meaningful electrical stimulation of the auditory nerve where degeneration of the hair cells in the cochlea has progressed to a point such that amplification provided by hearing aids is no longer effective.

 

The principle of cochlear implant surgery is to place the electrode array within the scala tympani of the cochlea. This allows the electrodes to be in close proximity to the spiral ganglion cells and their dendrites (that lie in the modiolus and osseous spiral lamina of the cochlea, respectively).

 

There are broadly two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation:

 

  1. The facial recess approach where a simple cortical mastoidectomy is done. The facial recess is opened by performing a posterior tympanotomy. The stapes, promontory and round window niche are identified. Cochleostomy is then performed anteroinferior to the round window membrane to a diameter of 1.0 - 1.6 mm depending on the electrode to be used.
  2. The pericanal techniques where a tympanomeatal flap is elevated to perform a cochleostomy either by endaural or postaural approach. In the pericanal techniques a bony tunnel is drilled along the external canal towards the middle ear. The examples of pericanal techniques include the Veria and suprameatal recess approach.

 

The following criteria help define candidacy for cochlear implantation:

 

  1. Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss.
  2. Little or no benefit from hearing aids.
  3. No medical contraindication for surgery.
  4. Realistic expectation.
  5. Good family and social support toward habilitation.
  6. Adequate cognitive function to be able to use the device.

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Round window - Not typically the site for electrode placement in cochlear implants.

 

Option B. Oval window - Also not used for electrode placement; this structure connects the middle ear to the inner ear.

 

Option C. Scala vestibuli - Another perilymph-filled cavity in the cochlea, but not the preferred location for electrode placement due to its anatomy and relation to the auditory pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The scala tympani is the preferred site for electrode placement in cochlear implant surgery to ensure optimal auditory nerve stimulation, highlighting the importance of precision in surgical approaches to maximize the benefits of the implant.

questions.text:
Mark the correct statement/s about Inner and Outer hair cells. (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses
  2. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate function of inner hair cells
  3. Outer hair cells are more responsible for movement of tectorial membrane
  4. Inner hair cells are in single row and modulate function of outer hair cells
  5. Outer and inner hair cells are present in the ratio 3:1
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 5 are correct 

This choice correctly identifies that inner hair cells transmit auditory impulses, outer hair cells are in multiple rows and aid in the functionality related to cochlear amplification, and that there is a numerical dominance of outer hair cells compared to inner hair cells. 

The correct statements regarding the roles and arrangements of inner and outer hair cells within the cochlea, based on the options given, are as follows:

1. Inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses: This statement is correct. Inner hair cells are primarily responsible for transmitting auditory signals to the brain. They are fewer in number compared to outer hair cells and are arranged in a single row along the length of the cochlea.

2. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate the function of inner hair cells: This is correct. Outer hair cells are indeed arranged in 3-4 rows. They play a crucial role in amplifying and fine-tuning the vibrations within the cochlea through their motility, which affects how the inner hair cells respond to sound. 

5. Outer and inner hair cells are present in the ratio 3:1: This statement is  correct. There are significantly more outer hair cells than inner hair cells, typically at a ratio close to 3:1, reflecting their arrangement in multiple rows compared to the single row of inner hair cells.

Other Options:

3. Outer hair cells are more responsible for the movement of the tectorial membrane: This statement is incorrect. Outer hair cells do contribute to the movement of the tectorial membrane through their motility and changes in length, but it's more accurate to say they influence the fluid mechanics around the inner hair cells, affecting how the tectorial membrane interacts with them.

4. Inner hair cells are in a single row and modulate function of outer hair cells: This statement is incorrect. Inner hair cells do not modulate the function of outer hair cells; rather, they function primarily as sensory transducers sending information to the brain.

Educational Objective: 

The correct statements about inner and outer hair cells are that inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses, outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and help modulate cochlear mechanics, and the ratio of outer to inner hair cells is about 3:1.

choices.text: Cold water induces nystagmus to same side
Directional preponderance occurs towards the side of Central lesion

questions.text: All of the following are true about Fitzgerald-Hallpike test, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cold water induces nystagmus to same side

 

Explanation:

 

The Fitzgerald-Hallpike test (bithermal caloric test) uses water at temperatures above and below body temperature to stimulate the horizontal semicircular canal and induce nystagmus. Cold water irrigation induces nystagmus to the opposite side, not the same side. This follows the mnemonic "COWS" (Cold-Opposite, Warm-Same), which indicates that cold water induces nystagmus to the opposite side while warm water induces nystagmus to the same side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bithermal Caloric Test: This is a correct statement. Fitzgerald-Hallpike test is indeed also known as the bithermal caloric test. It uses water at 30°C (cold) and 44°C (warm) to stimulate the horizontal semicircular canals.

 

Option C. Directional preponderance occurs towards the side of Central lesion: This is a correct statement. Directional preponderance (where nystagmus is stronger in one direction than the other) typically occurs toward the side of a central lesion, and away from the side in a peripheral lesion.

 

Option D. All are true: This option is incorrect because statement B is false. Cold water causes nystagmus to the opposite side, not the same side.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In the Fitzgerald-Hallpike caloric test, cold water irrigation causes nystagmus to the opposite side, following the mnemonic "COWS" (Cold-Opposite, Warm-Same), which is a fundamental principle in vestibular testing and helps differentiate various vestibular disorders.

questions.text:
What are the objective tests used to assess hearing?

 

  1. BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry)
  2. OAE (Otoacoustic emission)
  3. PTA (Pure tone audiometry)
  4. Tympanometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

 

Objective hearing tests are those that do not require a response from the patient and are used to assess hearing ability or the integrity of parts of the hearing pathway.

 

1. BERA - Also called BAER or BAEP (brainstem auditory evoked response or potential) is an objective test to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts. It is a noninvasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the VIIIth nerve, pons and midbrain

 

 

2. OAE is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by outer hair cells of a normal cochlea and can be elicited by a very sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal and analyzed by a computer.

 

4. Tympanometry is an objective test for compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system.

 

 

 

Other Option:

 

3. Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA): PTA requires the patient's active participation to indicate when a sound is heard. It tests the hearing threshold levels of an individual, enabling determination of the degree, type, and configuration of a hearing loss, thus classifying it as a subjective test.

 

Other examples of subjective tests include tuning fork tests and speech audiometry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Objective tests such as BERA, OAE, and Tympanometry provide essential diagnostic data without requiring any active response from the patient, thus suitable for use in patients who may not be able to respond reliably, such as young children or those with certain disabilities.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 25, 26, 29

questions.text: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laryngeal papilloma

 

The image depicts laryngeal papilloma.

 

Laryngeal papillomatosis (juvenile papillomatosis)

 

  • Juvenile papillomatosis is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children.
  • It is viral in origin and is caused by human papilloma virus type 6 and 11.
  • It is presumed that affected children got the disease at birth from their mothers who had vaginal human papillomavirus disease.
  • Papilloma’s mostly affect supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx but can also involve subglottis, trachea and bronchi. DNA virus particles have been found in the cells of the basement membrane of respiratory mucosa and may account for widespread involvement and recurrence.
  • Patients, often a child, between the age of 3 and 5 years present with hoarseness or aphonia with respiratory difficulty or even stridor.
  • Diagnosis is made by flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy and later confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy.
  • Papillomas are known for recurrence but rarely undergo malignant change.
  • Treatment consists of microlaryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision avoiding injury to vocal ligament. Other modalities of tumor removal are with cold steel instruments or  debrider or coblation or radiofrequency. Aim of therapy is to maintain a good airway, preserve voice and avoid recurrence.
  • Adjuvant medical therapies include Interferon alpha-2a and 13-cis-retinoic acid has been used.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Reinke's edema - Characterized by swelling of the vocal cords due to fluid accumulation, not similar to the warty growths of papillomas.

 

Option B. Malignancy - Would typically appear more irregular and could involve more invasive growth patterns.

 

Option C. Tracheomalacia - A condition related to the softening of the tracheal walls, not relevant to laryngeal lesions.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Laryngeal papilloma is a significant pediatric condition caused by HPV, manifesting as benign, wart-like growths within the larynx. While these tumors are prone to recurrence, they rarely undergo malignant transformation, making careful ongoing monitoring and management essential.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 345

questions.text: Which of the following is not another name for an inverted papilloma of the nose? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Juvenile papilloma

 

Explanation:


Juvenile papilloma is not a recognized alternative name for inverted papilloma of the nose. Inverted papilloma is a distinctive tumor of the nasal cavity that grows in an inverted fashion, with hyperplastic papillomatous tissue growing into the stroma rather than in an exophytic manner. It most commonly arises from the lateral wall of the nose in the middle meatus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transitional cell papilloma: This is a correct alternative name for inverted papilloma. The term relates to the transitional epithelium that lines the tumor.

 

Option B. Ringertz tumor: This is indeed another name for inverted papilloma, named after the pathologist who described its characteristic inverted growth pattern.

 

Option C. Schneiderian papilloma: This is a valid alternative name for inverted papilloma, referring to its origin from the Schneiderian membrane (the non-olfactory mucosa of the nose).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Inverted papilloma is known by several names including transitional cell papilloma, Ringertz tumor, and Schneiderian papilloma, reflecting its histological features and growth pattern, but juvenile papilloma is not among its recognized synonyms.

questions.text: Which phenomenon describes vertigo induced by loud sounds? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tullio Phenomenon

 

Explanation:

 

Tullio phenomenon refers to the development of vertigo and nystagmus in response to loud sounds. This occurs due to a pathological connection between the sound-conducting system and the vestibular apparatus. Loud sounds cause abnormal stimulation of the vestibular system, resulting in vestibular symptoms. This phenomenon is seen in conditions like superior semicircular canal dehiscence, perilymphatic fistula, and advanced otosyphilis where there is an abnormal communication between the inner ear fluid compartments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hennebert's Sign: This refers to the development of vertigo and nystagmus on applying pressure to the external auditory canal (positive fistula test) in the absence of a demonstrable fistula (false positive). It is typically seen in congenital syphilis due to the presence of fibrous adhesions between the stapes footplate and the membranous labyrinth. Unlike Tullio phenomenon which is triggered by sound, Hennebert's sign is elicited by pressure changes.

 

Option C. Roll-over Phenomenon: This is seen in retrocochlear hearing loss (e.g., acoustic neuroma). It refers to a decrease in speech discrimination scores as the intensity of sound is increased beyond a certain level. Unlike Tullio phenomenon, it does not involve vertigo and is related to hearing discrimination rather than vestibular function.

 

Option D. Recruitment Phenomenon: This is the abnormal growth of loudness perception seen in cochlear hearing loss. Patients with cochlear lesions have difficulty hearing soft sounds, but as intensity increases, they perceive loudness as rapidly growing to normal or even uncomfortable levels. This phenomenon affects hearing rather than balance and does not cause vertigo.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Tullio phenomenon specifically describes the vestibular symptoms (vertigo and nystagmus) induced by loud sounds due to pathological communication between the sound-conducting and vestibular systems of the inner ear.

questions.text: Which of the following devices can be used for managing a patient with B/L external auditory canal atresia?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A.

 

 

Image A shows Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) and it can be used in managing B/L external auditory canal atresia.

 

INDICATIONS FOR BAHA

 

  1. When air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:
  2. Canal atresia, congenital or acquired, not amenable to treatment.
  3. Chronic ear discharge, not amenable to treatment.
  4. Excessive feedback and discomfort from air-conduction hearing aid.
  5. Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g., otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis where surgery is contraindicated.
  6. Single-sided hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cochlear implant is an electronic device that can provide useful hearing and improved communication abilities for persons who have severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss and who cannot benefit from hearing aids.

 

Cochlear implants may be used both in children and adults. The following criteria help define candidacy for cochlear implantation:

 

  1. Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss.
  2. Little or no benefit from hearing aids.
  3. No medical contraindication for surgery.
  4. Realistic expectation.
  5. Good family and social support toward habilitation.
  6. Adequate cognitive function to be able to use the device.

 

Option C. Stapedectomy piston is used in otosclerosis patients.

 

Option D. Partial ossicular replacement prosthesis is used to replace the incudo-stapedial joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with bilateral external auditory canal atresia, BAHA is an excellent management option, leveraging bone conduction to bypass the outer and middle ear, thus facilitating hearing when traditional air-conduction devices cannot be used.

choices.text: Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel
Shift to OT, start IV antibiotics, and pack the tonsillar fossa
Give anticoagulants, repeated gargling, and wait for 24 hours
Do blood transfusion and wait and watch

questions.text: A patient post-tonsillectomy in the recovery room starts bleeding from the operative site. On examination, blood clots are seen. What will be your immediate management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel

 

The given clinical picture is suggestive of reactionary hemorrhage post-tonsillectomy and the immediate management is to shift the patient to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the bleeding vessel.

 

Hemorrhage is a common complication of tonsillectomy. It can be primary, reactionary, or secondary:

 

  • Primary hemorrhage occurs at the time of operation. It can be controlled by pressure, ligation, or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.
  • Reactionary hemorrhage occurs within 24 hours. It may be due to dislodgement of the clot, slippage of ligature, or blood pressure returning to normal. It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor. Ligation or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels is done under anesthesia if the above measures fail.
  • Secondary hemorrhage is usually seen between the 5th to 10th postoperative day. It is due to sepsis and premature separation of the membrane. Removal of the clot, topical application of dilute adrenaline or hydrogen peroxide with pressure usually suffice. IV antibiotics are given and the bleeding vessel is electro coagulated or ligated if bleeding continues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate return to the OT for direct intervention is essential in managing post-tonsillectomy bleeding. Ensuring the bleeding vessel is adequately addressed through cauterization or ligation can prevent further complications and promote healing.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 504, 505

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic ear infection presents with fever, headache, vomiting, irritability, and confusion. His CT brain is shown in the image below. What is the possible diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Temporal lobe abscess

 

The clinical vignette with the given CT image points to a diagnosis of temporal lobe abscess that is most likely to have developed as a complication of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM).

 

Temporal lobe abscess is an intracranial complication of CSOM.

 

Localizing symptoms of temporal lobe abscess -

 

  1. Nominal aphasia. If abscess involves dominant hemisphere, i.e. left hemisphere in right-handed persons, patient fails to tell the names of common objects such as key, pen, etc. but can demonstrate their use.
  2. Homonymous hemianopia. This is due to pressure on the optic radiations. Visual field, opposite to the side of the lesion, is lost. It can be elicited by confrontation test, by standing in front of the patient and comparing his visual field with that of the examiner, or by perimeter. The defect is usually in the upper, but sometimes in the lower quadrants.
  3. Contralateral motor paralysis. In the usual upward spread of abscess, the face is involved first followed by the arm and leg. Inward spread, towards the internal capsule, involves the leg first followed by the arm and the face.
  4. Epileptic fits. Involvement of uncinate gyrus causes hallucinations of taste, and smell and involuntary smacking movements of lips and tongue. Generalized fits may occur.

 

CT brain is the investigation of choice. Brain abscess is seen as a ring-enhancing lesion in imaging studies.

 

Management:

 

  1. IV antibiotics (usually third generation cephalosporin +/- metronidazole) are started. Aminoglycosides are added if pseudomonas infection is suspected. Culture and sensitivity of ear swabs can guide antibiotic therapy.
  2.  Raised intracranial tension can be lowered by dexamethasone, 4 mg i.v. 6 hourly or mannitol 20% in doses of 0.5 g/kg body weight
  3. Surgical: Abscess drainage of the temporal lobe abscess followed by radical mastoidectomy for CSOM is the definitive management in such cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cerebellar abscess: Would likely present with different symptoms, including severe dizziness, balance problems, and coordination difficulties.

 

Option C. Subdural abscess: Usually presents with more diffuse cerebral symptoms and different radiological features.

 

Option D. Meningitis: Characterized by severe headache, neck stiffness, and photophobia, with different findings on lumbar puncture and imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Temporal lobe abscess is a serious complication of chronic ear infections that requires prompt recognition and aggressive treatment to prevent further neurological damage and potential life-threatening complications.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition pg 90, 91

questions.text: A child presents with trismus and painful limb spasms following a recent untreated ear infection. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tetanus

 

This presentation describes otogenic tetanus, a rare but serious complication of ear infections. The combination of trismus (difficulty opening mouth) and limb spasms following an ear infection is pathognomonic for tetanus. The tetanus organism (Clostridium tetani) can invade through the infected ear, particularly when there is tympanic membrane perforation. The bacteria enter the middle ear space, get absorbed systemically, and release neurotoxins that affect the muscular system, causing the characteristic muscle spasms and lockjaw. Early treatment with tetanus immunoglobulin is crucial - if untreated, mortality approaches 100%, but early intervention can achieve 80% success rates.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Meningitis: While this can be a complication of ear infections, it typically presents with neck stiffness, headache, fever, and altered consciousness rather than the specific combination of trismus and limb spasms.

 

Option C. Sigmoid sinus thrombosis: This complication presents with hectic fever, Griesinger sign (mastoid edema), and increased intracranial pressure, not with muscle spasms and trismus.

 

Option D. Bezold's abscess: This is a deep neck abscess that tracks along the sternocleidomastoid muscle, presenting as neck swelling and pain, not with neuromuscular symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Otogenic tetanus presents with trismus and muscle spasms following ear infection and requires immediate tetanus immunoglobulin therapy.

questions.text: From which of the following structures does the saccule develop? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pars inferior

 

The saccule develops from pars inferior.

 

Development of internal ear:

 

  • Development of the inner ear starts in the 3rd week of fetal life and is complete by the 16th week. Ectoderm in the region of hindbrain thickens to form an auditory placode, which is invaginated to form auditory vesicles or the otocyst. The latter then differentiates into the endolymphatic duct and sac; the utricle, the semicircular ducts; and saccule and the cochlea. Development of the phylogenetically older part of labyrinth—pars superior (semicircular canals and utricle) takes place earlier than pars inferior (saccule and cochlea).

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Saculus anterior - Not a term typically associated with the development of the ear's structures.

 

Option B. Saculus posterior - Similarly, this is not a recognized term in the developmental anatomy of the ear.

 

Option C. Pars superior - Incorrect, as this part contributes to the development of the semicircular canals and utricle, not the saccule.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The developmental origins of the inner ear structures, such as the saccule from the pars inferior, is crucial for comprehending various auditory and vestibular functions, as well as pathologies associated with these areas.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 13

questions.text: Inspiratory stridor is found in what kind of lesions: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supraglottic

 

  • Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions.
  • Types of stridor and sites of origin
    • Inspiratory stridor - laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
    • Expiratory stridor - bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.
    • Biphasic stridor - laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis and subglottic stenosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subglottic - More commonly associated with biphasic stridor due to narrowing at the level just below the vocal cords.

 

Option C. Tracheal - Can cause either biphasic or expiratory stridor depending on the extent and exact location of the obstruction.

 

Option D. Bronchus - Primarily causes expiratory stridor due to obstructions in the lower airways.

 

Educational Objective:


Inspiratory stridor is a key clinical sign indicating a potential obstruction in the supraglottic region of the airway. Recognizing this symptom is critical for diagnosing and managing airway obstructions effectively to prevent respiratory distress.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 333, 334

questions.text: The vertical and horizontal fracture of nasal septum is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chevallet and Jarjaway fracture

 

  • Chevallet fracture - Fracture line runs vertically from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of the bony and cartilaginous dorsum of the nose.

 

 

  • Jarjaway fracture - Fracture line starts just above the anterior nasal spine and runs horizontally backward just above the junction of septal cartilage with the vomer.

 

 

Tripod fracture – is zygomatic fracture. Zygoma is separated into three processes. Fracture line passes through zygomaticofrontal suture, orbital floor, infraorbital margin and foramen, anterior wall of maxillary sinus and the zygomaticotemporal suture

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Citelli fracture - This does not pertain to the nasal septum but rather involves other cranial structures.

 

Option C. Tripod fracture - This is a zygomatic fracture where the zygoma is separated into three processes. The fracture line passes through the zygomaticofrontal suture, orbital floor, infraorbital margin and foramen, anterior wall of the maxillary sinus, and the zygomaticotemporal suture, unrelated to the nasal septum fractures.

 

Educational Objective:


The Chevallet and Jarjaway fractures are important classifications in the context of nasal injuries, describing vertical and horizontal fractures of the nasal septum respectively. Understanding these fracture types aids in accurate diagnosis and management of nasal trauma.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 166
